content: 2020 has left this room largely unused for actual gaming and it's given
me a lot of time to reflect on that part of the hobby and
why i've been struggling with it for a long time
hey guys welcome back to blackmagic
craft so the first half of 2020 has been
largely awful in just about every way imaginable i've
been trying to make the best of it and count my blessings but
it's hard not to get down in the dumps with everything that's gone
on in the world over the past few months one of the many consequences of the
pandemic is the indefinite shutdown of my
dnd game this break made me come to terms with something i've known for
quite a while but wouldn't admit i'm really not into d
d anymore well hold up a second just bear with me what
i mean is i just haven't been motivated or
excited to run dnd games a lot of this stems from
the fact that i'm really yearning to just play a game where i can
show up drink some beer socialize and not have to worry about all the work
that is involved in being a dm when you're
running a game it can be the most rewarding gaming experience imaginable
but it can also be a big burden and it can come with a lot of pressure to make
sure that everybody else is getting that great
gaming experience sometimes at the cost of you getting it for yourself
i'm totally content making terrain for videos to help you guys with your games
and i found a fantastic outlet in building dioramas but still my heart has
been aching because i've been missing that other vital part of the
hobby playing games for a period me and a few
friends played around with other games that would give me that freedom to just
show up and play and not have to work during the game frostgrave was a
really good fit for a while but unfortunately the guys i was playing
with sort of lost interest i tried to bring
myself a bit into their world and do something warhammer related but i
really wasn't keen to fall headfirst into the massive pit that is
40k or age of sigmar they figured we'd meet in the middle and try
kill team i played a game and it was fun and i
even started assembling a roster of models for it i finished my pox walkers
but never got past the assembly and priming stage for my plague marines
over the past two weeks after much reflecting about my relationship with
gaming and hobbying things suddenly aligned in a way that
created a spark open play warhammer 40k the answer had been in plain sight the
whole time but it took three things happening in short
succession for me to come to this realization
thing the first trent my friend trent from miscast and his series of
nurgle diary videos in these my eyes were
open to the fact that warhammer modeling could be a lot less restrictive
than i had thought it got me thinking about those death guard models i had
sitting on the shelf for nearly a year and how much i also loved the aesthetic
of plague marines pox walkers and nurgle demons thing the second my close
friend jp and i got to talking about restarting some sort of
game and what we could play this time around he again suggested playing
warhammer i expressed some concern that i had over
certain aspects of the game and he said there was a perfect solution
narrative gaming the plan would be to play some open games with a low power
for me to get a handle on the rules and then transition
into a more narrative style play that would be a perfect fit for both of us
thing the third 28 mag and the whole world of blanchitsu modeling
i had been familiar with this style for quite a while and i've always loved it
what i didn't know is that this aesthetic went way beyond just
painting style and was in fact a whole movement a whole community
this was the final push i needed looking through that magazine at all these
alternative modeling styles that i really connected with
and reading articles about the mentality behind them
was exactly what i needed to realize that warhammer
actually was right for me because just like d
turns out warhammer can be anything you want it to be
i was determined to not only paint those plague marines that had been collecting
dust but to build a full and proper death guard army i ordered a bunch of
stuff to get started but first i had to conquer that small
intimidating mountain that was painting the plague marines
i actually did something i never do i tested out a bunch of techniques on two
of the models before committing to a plan
i was gonna approach this whole paint job and the
new warhammer venture differently i wasn't gonna just wing it i wanted to
take time to find out how to best paint these guys in a way that balanced how
they looked how hard it was to do and how enjoyable the process was so i
allocated some time to experimenting before committing and i learned that the
contrast paint that i had landed on using for the base coat
did in fact work better when the model was primed with a citadel primer versus
the vallejo primer that i already had sitting on them
so i reprimed them all i set out a basic plan of attack with a minimal amount of
paints this would grow significantly over the
coming days the idea of going into this paint job not worrying about
so many of the things that intimidated me about painting warhammer models
was really refreshing the whole 28 mag aesthetic was
so well suited for me personally that i could finally go at these models with
excitement rather than fear i didn't have to worry
about any imaginary warhammer painting rules
although i did respect certain established rules because well
they're good rules my plan with these guys was to not worry about every little
detail on the model and how to paint them individually but instead focus on
major material elements covering transitions and
how to combine all the elements in sufficient levels of texture and grime
to really sell that nurgle vibe these guys
weren't gonna be all about a million edge highlight details i wanted them to
be rich in detail but i wanted those details to be a variety of textures
filth and finishes i wanted every part of these models to look interesting when
focused on but i wanted to achieve this through
layers of filth rather than layers of perfect painting details so
while i was still putting a lot of time and effort into
them and paying attention to the million little sculptural details
that gw always includes i wasn't stressing
about it i don't know how to fully convey this
amazing change of mindset i had while working on these figures
gw models have always been this point of contention for me
i disliked them i disliked them because they were too over the top and because
they often came with a lot of stigma and judgment about how you may
have painted yours i guess in all honesty i was scared to
really get into painting them because i was nervous about getting crucified by
people on the internet who were so involved in this particular hobby that
they knew every lore detail and how it relates to painting an army or
who have spent 20 years perfecting edge highlighting
the moment i realized i could ignore all of that and just attack these in any
which way i wanted was the moment i felt this great feeling of freedom
and an overwhelming sense of excitement that i hadn't felt in
anything hobby related for quite some time when i started this hobby i used to
spend most nights staying up really late
crafting and painting but over the past year or so
that has stopped spending the majority of my days
already working on stuff for the channel has been more than enough for me
and i haven't felt that alluring pull to work on things into the wee hours of the
morning i didn't feel that need that desire or
excitement to just keep painting and keep building but
these crusty plague boys changed all of that i found myself
feeling this need to work on them over the weekend and into the late hours of
the night this felt a little bit like coming home
suddenly i found myself listening to hours of warhammer lore
videos while painting plague swords and both guns if you told me this several
months ago hell even a few weeks ago that this is
how i would be spending my evenings i absolutely would not have believed you
but here i am and honestly i couldn't be happier about
it i also found myself wanting to continually take things
further where i normally might say yup this looks good enough i can stop
found myself wanting to just add one more thing one more detail one more
effect and each time i did it it got me more excited
and it pushed me to taking it even further while i experienced this with
building things quite frequently i rarely experience it while
painting them i almost never experience it while
painting character minis i finally learned this whole
satisfaction of excessive detail that i normally
don't understand about mini painting i now know why it can be so enjoyable to
spend hours on one small aspect of a model
or its paint job the trick for me was simply making those details crusty and
gross instead of pristine and clean i know
that the whole blanchitsu approach of mini painting comes with
some negative connotations and it's not something everybody really likes or even
respects i also know that it's often used as a
bit of an excuse for poor painting ability i think i could
easily fall into that trap of just slapping crud onto a model to hide low
skill level but i don't think that's what i did here
i think i actually put in a valiant effort and a good amount of
artistic ability enough to make it a legitimately good
attempt i don't know if these models actually could be classified as blind
too proper i don't really know what all the rules are
although i don't know if there really are defined rules but i
you know i don't care and i don't care in a positive way
these models are mine and their aesthetic is mine
and i love them i love them so much that i went for an incredibly minimal base
which is the opposite of what i normally do usually i highly decorate a base to
distract from the mini's paint job to kind of trick people into thinking it
looks better than it really does but here i wanted
plain bases that served as a frame and i didn't want them distracting from the
paint job that i was so happy with it's funny
even after clear coating as it was adding the final glossy effects i felt
myself kind of sad that these models were coming to
completion despite having a mountain of other models that needed assembly and
painting for my army i just sort of didn't want to stop working on these
guys i don't think i've ever experienced that
before and it's a pretty monumental thing for me
i of course cannot deny that peeling these guys off the pill bottle prisms
that they had been on for at least a year was by far the most
satisfying hobby moment i've had in ages at this point in time
these models are the thing that i am most proud of i may not have built them
myself like i can say about the terrain or
diorama that i make but i put so much of myself into their paint job
and i'm so satisfied with the results that
these models really are something special for me they represent not only
accomplishing a task that i had procrastinated for ages but they
represent myself opening up to another corner of the
hobby that i had previously not only been reluctant to do but almost
aggressively against mindsets can be a hard thing to change
but there's nothing in life more fulfilling than questioning and
changing your mindset or opinion be it a worldview or something to do with your
hobby it doesn't matter focusing yourself to look inward and
change your opinion on something is one of the most important things you
can do as a human being i think if we all did that a little more
we'd be happier hobbyists and we'd live in a much more stable
world the irony of painting plague marines
as a result of my dnd game being shut down by a literal plague
is not lost on me and in some ways it makes this whole experience and journey
a lot more fitting this has opened a whole world of new hobby possibilities
for me and i couldn't be happier about it
don't worry this channel isn't going full warhammer but things related to
warhammer modeling specifically this alternative style of warhammer modeling
will surely become a more regular part of it i'm at the beginning of a new
hobby journey and i really want to share that with you
guys this channel has always existed to teach people how to do
things but more importantly it existed with the sole purpose of inspiring
specifically inspiring people to try new things and to not be afraid to jump head
first into new hobbies this week i took my own advice and i'm
really glad that i did if you enjoyed this video please hit the
like button and let me know your thoughts in the comments section below
doing so really means a lot and it helps these videos reach a lot more people
if you want to jump into some new corner of the hobby and you need some tools or
supplies to do it please check out my essential equipment page on
blackmagicraft.com it's a great resource for understanding
the tools of the trade and using that page really helps out
this channel and if you want to help me continue this
channel and doing what i do consider supporting it on patreon
if it wasn't for the support there i wouldn't be able to hang out with you
guys every week and show you what's going on in my hobby
life i love you all thanks for watching but now get out
there go get to work on that hobby project you've
been too scared to try you'll probably be happy that you did
